? Not because "N on the rim is grim" (I hate that rhyme!), but because the WQ can't go to h5 and check. If so, this N assures g6 can't be played to stop the check, on behalf of Nxg6, being a7 pinned to the R. But not now, since the Nf6 is there.
Expecting a defeat, I go on (never backwards! :-)
Expecting a defeat, I go on (never backwards! :-)
Well, just where he shouldn't castle! My attack (if any at all!) is aiming there!
Nxg4, BxN, fxB, Qg4, defending the Na4 with Rg1, and hoping in some black mistake...
? Just opens the way for my R to his king. No fork, since BxN, but then
Now the exchange situation is becoming better: I can interpose, after Nxg4, BxBe7, QxB, BxN, fxB, Qxg4 and the N is defended.
I'm not forced to exchange pieces.
This is more subtle, but the column will become free soon. If h5, f3.
...good!, adding a defender to g4. But...
I remove one of them.
The N doesn't "hangs" anymore, thanks to Rg1, since after BxN, BxB+ and we are on even terms (any move to shield the check and my B retires).

This was losing, but it was hard to see it.
True, my Q has not a mate right now, but...

? Better was Kf7. Why? It's hard to see. Black is based on the fact that the next move he can play Rg8 and kick my Q away. No matter if it goes Qh5, since Qe8 can follow, stopping Ng6+. But white (take into account, learners!) seems to have a shocking way to end the game.
After hxN, black seems to be lost, due to a well-known mate pattern.
That's all? Yes! Because the Q is threatening mate on h6 (or h5). Rf7 is losing the R for nothing, and...

Seems to save the day, but it's not true, because the Rf8 will become undefended.
My opponent resigned here, on the basis of the following sequence:

So, as black, be aware of this kind of attack (you will face, probably, sooner or later), and as white, "be nastier than normal", when attacking: don't stick to the more obvious moves, always look for more moves. You will find some useful surprise, like this one I found on the way.
